title: Links For April 2014
summary:
Key Ideas:
- Korean corporation purchased land in Canada for an agricultural project but never grew any crops
- UFO cult built a clinic in Burkina Faso to reverse female genital mutilation and accuses the Catholic Church of thwarting them
- Kenya’s high use of mobile-phone based money transfer makes it fertile ground for cryptocurrency use
- Awareness weeks to reduce stigma may actually increase self-stigma
- Norway's army addressed sexual harassment by making men and women share rooms and encouraging similar hairstyles
- People have more positive emotions towards words typed primarily with the right hand
- A study finds 90% of academic papers are never cited, up to 50% are never read by anyone except authors and peer reviewers
- Garden path sentences are a cool way to observe the hidden mechanisms of one's brain at work
- Female wealth and education may increase risk of violence instead of decreasing it
- Gifted children allowed to skip grades are much more likely to get doctoral degrees, patents, and STEM PhDs
- Higher levels of creatine may be linked to better labor market outcomes and preliminary studies find it to be effective against depression

Key Learnings:
- Cultures can influence crime and must be considered in medical diagnoses
- Crowdfunded investment of new companies for as little as $100 may be one of the most important economic events of the decade
- Being a gifted child has significant positive impacts, but schools allocate less than 1/2000th the funding for gifted education as special education for low performers

Key Questions:
- How did clowns become scary when children are born with a fear of them?
- Are genetic copy-number variants really important in understanding interesting psychosocial phenomena?
- Should gifted children not be held back by offending others or the lack of funding for gifted education?
